review_blob: The qilin is one of the coolest beer mascots. I just wish they had a product to match the coolness of the qilin. On the marketing gimmick, I do have trust on the honesty of the Japanese traceability system. So perhaps when they write "single malt", perhaps they do mean it. It does not mean though this will be a great beer. Its Kirin, after all. Burpsy sweet stench, decent gold colour with suave white head, and an incredibly surprising bitter taste. Grassy, metallic bitter, rough edge, perhaps too dry, unexpected for the brand. I would not have another one though.

This is proper beer. Bottle from a family mart - type of place. Nice and copper, with a rather unfulfilling head, lovely aroma of honey, syrup, dried stone fruits and the fruity hops. Flavour goes along the same way. It feels like a rather old double IPA, very mellow and syrupy. Thick on the palate, this is my choice from now on for this selection near my hotel.

Lovely beer. Do not expect an explosion of flavours, but it is dry, it looks amazing, it is ashy on the taste buds and creamy on the palate (it would take a 5 for the creamy head, but the beer itself is rather thin). Lovely dry stout from Japan. Something that is called "dry" and actually good here.

I dont particularly like the style, but this was pretty damn good. Looks spectacular, pure double cream on top, nice aroma and taste of bubble gum, a bit like the white (blue) 1664, and incredibly dense/creamy on the palate.

Honestly, I cannot see much of a difference on these Japanese pale lagers with different labels. Tastes and looks and smells like the vast majority of dry beers from Japan. A different look for a different niche, but with the same content in the bottle. This one has a particular late bitterness, rather metallic, which is nothing to be excited about. And it lacks the qilin on the label, making it even more boring.

I found this in a supermarket in Korea, among cans of European-sounding Asian beers. I didnt expect much, as I bought it only for the tick mark. And the beer did not surprise me. It does have an interesting grassy Saaz bitterness, Besides that, it is the usual bready dull. Tick!
If it wasnt for a bit of bitterness (roasted malts) to countrbalance the chocolate sweetness, Id say its a brown ale. Thin, but quite harmless and certainly a pleasant drink.

The aroma is rather malty, but the flavour has a wider range of challenges to the taste buds, with karo, sweet mandarins and a touch of English Bitter-style hops. Its true amber coloured, kinda rich, but with a non-mentionable head. Nice and well-bodied on the palate.

Picked up the wrong bottle at a convenience store in Tokyo. I had intended to buy the Bruin. Anyway, this is nice, golden, spicy and rather well bodied, with an incredible aroma and flavour of fruity bubble gum. Its not bad!

Smoked? Gimme a break. Yes, it is smoked, but it does not change the style. Smoked is only a style on its own when mimicking the famous Bamberg beers. This is a Baltic Porter, and a great "German" one, truly for a change. Nice and sweet, with cocoa and dark fruits, that smoked bacon tinge and with a sweet aroma of chocolate and hickory. Black as a shoe, with a nice russet head, it lacks some saltiness to be a massive BP, but it has that lovely oily palate. Great job! For fans of Baltic Porters!
beer_name: Stiegl / Maisel & Friends Smoked Baltic Porter

review_blob: Bottle, from a convenience store by the Tokyo Dome. Mr Pearse Lyons is not only a great marketing man, but very much a visionary. Who else would dare to call his single-malt bourbon a "Single Malt Bourbon"? Considering this ale was the brewerys first product, I think theyve done a tremendous job. Nice and sweet, with a beautiful copper colour and a faint aroma of root beer, it melts in the mouth with flavours of caramel and a basket of autumn fruits in the cellar. Not too complex, it is smooth in the palate, quite velvety. Straightforward and honest. Another very decent flagship for the state of Kentucky. Well done, Alltech!

Not a stout. Clear brown, watery looking, but with nice aroma of malts, caramels and berries. Flavours of chocolate, malts, a touch of bitterness, and some artificial berry syrup Thin on the palate. Okay, but not a stout.

Finally a Niederschisch Baltic Porter (I know its only the North Sea out there) and its a good one! Dark brown, opaque, with a creamy beige head. The aroma is slightly hoppy, if not bland. Oops, will this be a herbal concoction? No. The flavour is somewhat herbal hoppy, but quite agreeable. Theres ashes and waxy chocolate in balance with that hops bitterness. Sour berries too, but that dark, cheap waxy chocolate is the tone that dominates in the end. Medium bodied, perhaps just was well, when carrying that load of herbalness. I rather like the overall result.

I have to say that when I saw this beer, I thought that maybe Id be finally trying a German Baltic Porter with the quality and taste of a good Polish one. Perhaps it was the name, which seems to have been well studied (I new it did not stand for bacillary rickettsia-like organisms and there is no etymological truth on their explanation on the back label, as my name happens to have the same root used for the city name), with that , certainly alluring. Besides, I have great admiration for anything Berlin. Well, it is not a Zywiec or a Kormoran, but it equals other Baltic ones, such as a Utenos or an Aldaris. Slightly boozey and bourbon amber/brown, it is malty, grainy, sweet, on the brink of cloyness, medium bodied, still somewhat resinous on the tongue. There is a rather artificial tone of dried fruits and Karamalz on the flavour and aroma. Bock? Yes, that too. In spite of its many defects and the unnecessary and blas use of the word "philosophy", I still love the marketing and, for those who are into all kinds of Baltic Porters, it is not a bad drinking experience.
Just as bad as its 12 - Werder Bremen - sister. Skunky, watery, bready, sweet, its hard to go down. Worse than Becks.

As a fan of Werder Bremen, I do find the comments below rather offensive. But not as offensive as the pityful quality of this beer. What can a team do? If rugby fans drink Heineken at the RWC, Werder fans might as well put up with this.

Bottle from a liquor store in Kuala Lumpur. The beer is quite sweet, with vanilla and a certain fake chocolate flavour. Never mind the appearance, as it looks quite nice and black, but its rather watery. Nothing offensive, but... meh...

Oily black, with a dark russet head. Aroma is very fragrant, alcoholic, but still with a hint of leather and olives, indicating the heavily hopped nature of the stout. Flavours of dark chocolate, vanilla and leather. Double expresso too, but not nasty, still controlled by the cocoa bitter-sweetness. Very evident booze, and a rather resinous feel to the palate. I was never a fan of the Brewdog presentation, but this bas-relief label is pretty damn cool!

Black, tan head, lovely aroma of dark chocolate and cherries. Less berry character on the flavor, but still the cocoa, liquorice, and roasted malts. Softly salted, a roasted bitterness to nicely balance the sweetness, it has a medium body and a lovely silky feel. Pretty much what I expect from a porter.
I think the official description does a lot of justice to this beer. Indeed a dessert porter, with dark chocolates and black cherries, tart, tart as promised. Vinous and black, beautiful creature.

I was excited to try this one, given that unforgettable Belgian Stout they produced in 2013. Well, it was not quite as rewarding this time. The beer has a spectacular shiny blackness that gives a great contrast to its brown caramel head. But the aroma was a turn off, as I got durian, yes, that rather nauseous stench of an Asian street market, way over too fruity and herbal for a stout. The flavour included a strong vein of perfumed baby wipes, some coffee and a nice dark chocolate. As the level in the pint lowers, the flavours settle to a less aromatic result, more towards a bitter chocolate character. Medium bodied. I hate to say it, but it doesnt do much to me.
beer_name: Emersons Cellar Reserve Tribulation Imperial Stout

review_blob: Citrus-yellow, turbid, not a pretty picture. The sour aroma of lemon, pears and yeast told me this was not going to be a rewarding experience, but I was wrong. The flavor is actually a lot less pungent than the appearance or the aroma would suggest. Certainly spicy and tart, but a bit of that pear tart (not tart as in tart, neither as in tart, but as in tart) sweetness which breaks the tartness a bit. The beer is thin-bodied and easier to drink than I would normally expect. Full of surprises, I guess. It does come across to me as a coriander-spiced white Belgian beer.
beer_name: Emersons Dinner Bell Belgian Table Beer

review_blob: Bottle, thanks to the kindness of Jimthechap. Id have kept it for over one year, but I do have reasons to open it now. Its overall very yeasty. Not sure whether Brettanomyces, but it does smell and tastes of it. Rather sour, it did not have the sweet, mellow character of other Biere de Guarde that I have tried. It was lemony, fruity, aromatic, almost soapy. Its a nice beer, dont get me wrong, but not what I expected as per the label.
beer_name: Renaissance Enlightenment Series Bire de Garde

review_blob: Pours beautifully, dark reddish amber with a white head, aromas of fresh hops, dried stone fruits and malts. The flavours do include these three items, but more emphasis on the grassy, almost metallic hoppy bitterness, not nearly as colourful as their glorious Bird Dog IPA. There is also a strong pine needle presence. This is a nice beer, with a resinous mouthfeel and it indeed warms you up as described by the manufacturers. The downside is the sad realization that we have no central heat and that Ive got a pathetic heat pump at home.

This is an aptly-named product. Not a black ale, but a rather brown, ruby, oakish, oily look, with a decent beige head, but rather bubbly, not too creamy. Aromas of dark chocolates and red berries, nice, but unfortunately I had it too cold, which perhaps toned down the power in the nose. Flavours of mocha indeed, but suave, not too coffeish, neither herbal. Dark chocolate and a very pleasant vinous character, perhaps those drops of oak. The body is rather light, making it nice and easy to drink. Not really the combo I expect from a porter, but it is a terribly pleasant beer!

I had this bottle for some 3 years before finally opening it. Brownish amber - I rarely use the word "amber", but here I think that it does apply. Lovely aromas of sweet caramel and booze. Nice, malty on the tongue, sweet and rather spicy, more of the bakery stuff, such as allspice, with dried apricots and stone fruits.Full bodied, great concoction!

Ruby black with a rosy, tan head. Looks pretty spectacular, promising a great foreign stout. Then, the wonderful aroma of dark chocloates, vanilla and berries. Nice touch of soy sauce there too... but the flavour breakes down into a teapot full of herbs. The Kruter element here is just too pungent, unpleasant. The same sin of the porter. These guys make great pale beers, but the dark ones have not been that good.
beer_name: Anchor Argonaut Collection: Flying Cloud San Francisco Stout

review_blob: Excellent surprise to find it in a bottle, in Hamilton (NZ). Black, with a beije, almost rosy head. Lovely aromas of dark chocolates, roasted malts, vanilla and red berries. Same on the flavour. Perfectly balanced, with sweetness and a touch of bitterness, never herbal. The beer is a bit too thin on the palate, not as stout as a stout porter should be, but its beautiful stuff anyway.

Not sure where the "amber lager" qualification is coming from. No jeweller would pay a price for amber of this colour. This is a schwarzbier or a dunkel, although its sweetness does make it taste more like one of those brazilian Malzbier. Its quite alright, with some roastiness and even a feeble berry note, although the sweetness is a bit off-putting. Too thin.
Medium bodied stout, with nice notes of roasted malts, dark chocolates, some plums, molasses and a lovely roasty bitterness. Not unforgettable, but good!

The porter looks somewhat thin, translucent. Strong presence of Vanilla Coke on both aroma and flavours, nearly smothering the nice chocolate character. The beer lacks body. Should have been denser, velvetier on the tongue.

Dark brown, with a nice aroma of dark chocolate and a red-vinous scent too. That is also present on the flavour, those berries, that grant this beer a lovely character. A bit of coffee, but never too much, this porter is nice and easy to drink. Although I have little time for the references of "Australian Immigrant" I do love the label design.

If you are in Peru, I recommend you take this over the red or the lager. It is not an exciting beer, but it is much more tolerable than its sisters. Pretty harmless, thin, it has that inoffensive aroma and flavour of toasted malts, toffee and molasses.

The idea of maracuya (passion fruit) in beer is utterly exciting. Would this be any better than passion-fruit flavours and aromas from hops? Unfortunately, for a passion fruit lover, in reality this will not correspond to the excitement of the idea. Perhaps because of the addition of peruvian physalys (aguaymanto), the boredon of the physalys maybe neutralises the sensations that passion fruit could offer. It is a nice pale ale though, aromatic, flavourful, a bit thin on the palate, but just fine!

"Ooh, I love quinua!!!" Right, just kidding. I would not use three exclamation marks. Neither would I waste the term "love" with such a flavourless grain. The beer is as harmless as quinua. Equally odourless and tasteless. Still, harmless. And why is that a Klsch?

I never noticed the label mentioning coffee. I was just disappointed to smell and taste that acrid streak of ripening coffee berries (yes, they are berries, not beans) in what would have been a perfectly reasonable porter. My mistake. But if you are quite happy to taste cold coffee in your beer...

Very enjoyable foreign stout from Brazil. I have no idea what an acai is or what it tastes like, but the deScription seem to match the berry tiones it gives this stout. There are some fruity notes (red berry-like) on the aroma and flavours. The dark chocolate is intense, but bitter and very lively, never too sweet. A dash of soy sauce and a lovely roasty bitterness, never herbal, just pleasant. The beer is velvety on the palate. This would make a great export to replace that dreadful Xingu.

Bottle, thanks to the courtesy of the lovely Marta & Marcos Andrino. This is another creation of the clever Colorado Brewery. I had no idea what Cauim was. It seems to be the name of the fermented yucca beer produced in the South American jungle. It pays to mention that this cauim is fermented by the yeasts in the saliva of the squaws, who chew the yucca before spitting it inside a gourd. Luckily (or not), that has nothing to do with this beer. Apparently it takes yucca on its recipe, but I could not tell where it is. It seems to me as a perfectly "normal" Pilsener, with a rather skunky aroma, a nice appearance, golden with a formidable creamy head (before it quickly disappears, with no traces of having existed). The flavour has a slightly grassy bitterness, expected from Saaz hops, but not as metallic as I would expect from a true Pilsener. Maltiness is quite strong, not cloying sweet, but it makes the beer not as easy to drink as hoped.

This was an amazing beer. labelled as "Ithaca", I ordered it through some online store in Brazil, before my visit. If you read portuguese, DrAlexandre (below) has a comprehensive history of this beer in what it refers to its name. The beer has a lovely dense black colour, with a thick (but not too creamy) brown head. Aromas of dark chocolates, molasses, nuts and raisins. The flavour is dark chocolates over the malts and that lovely "rapadura" (molasses brick) / toffee, that gives its enticing sweetness, balancing it perfectly against the roasted bitterness. Nutty, buttery, velvety and thick, it has a powerful body and the whole combination of challenges to our senses never gives us any hint of the rather high ABV. A thousand times better than its herbal sister, the Demoiselle, I thouroughly regret that I only ordered one bottle.

Quite disappointing. Either I took it too cold, as it is locally done, or this bottle offered hardly any flavour, body or aromas. No sensations. Easy to drink, of course, but forgotten in a split of a second.

beer_brewer_name: Cervecera del sur del Peru (Backus & Johnston - SABMiller)
review_blob: This was a good attempt at a decent Weizenbier. It could have some more of banana bubblegum and cloves, but it was a nice surprise. Highly recommendable, if you see this bottle at your local Andean shop while on tourism in Peru.

beer_brewer_name: Cervecera del sur del Peru (Backus & Johnston - SABMiller)
review_blob: The worst of the Cusquen(y)as. Not particularly vile, but absolutely flavourless and odourless. Sparkling water would have been a lot better.

I had this quite a while ago, in an uncanny can with a Boticelli image and a Maori name. I have no notes, but I remember it being lovely, full of fruits (grapefruits, passion and melons) on the nose and flavours. One of those typical New Zealand IPAs with delightful hoppy sensations that were so proud of. Named after a soon-to-be compulsory holiday, but still beautiful as that Italian Venus.

Bottle at the airport in Santiago. Dark brown, watery looking, with a brief off-white head. Malty, nutty, not much bitterness there. Some herbal scent and a bit of a foil bite. Makes it more of a Dunkel than a Bock. Innocuous. Boring but harmless.

Pint, at the Arequipa Beer Club. This is one of my least favourite styles, and the servers did fail to advise me that the IPA on tap was a black one. As it was also the only beer on tap, I was happy to take it anyway. And happier to have done it. The aroma is quite pleasant, GRASSY, fruity, straight forward hoppy IPA. Brown colour, dark, almost muddy. Flavour is surprisingly balanced for a black IPA, not too herbal, not too roasty bitter, but with a firm hops presence, giving it a lovely fruity note that combines well with is resinous piney palate. This pint disappeared much faster than I expected. Best beer in Peru so far.
UPDATED: JUL 21, 2015

Bootle from Vivanda supermarket. Miraflores. Dark walnut brown. Coffe and chocolate on the aroma and flavour, with a rather herbal bitterness. Thin bodied, a nice alternative from the usual lagers. I stll think they should make a sweet one, based on Inka Cola.

Bottle, courtesy of the most excellent Jimthechap - thanks Jono! I never know what to expect from a beer defined as "amber ale". This one would be better described as "A Bitter, And A Pretty Damn Good One". It is indeed biscuity and malty like a traditional bitter, but it has this raw hoppiness that grants the beer a lovely grapefruitiness on the aroma, and especially flavour. Its resinous enough for a rather low IBV. Good one!

My amusement with Chinese marketing strategies with no regard to product quality has no end. The aroma here was even a bit misleading. Quite pleasant, crisp, grassy, metallic. The rest is shite. Watery, sweet, tasteless. Nothing that is too bad for a chicken marinade. And the bad taste in the mouth can always be washed down with a lovely oyster stout. 
This was not the NBA version - perhaps the sponsorship is over. And I am not even sure whether my bottle was coming from the Shenzhen plant. The characters in the back label are so tiny and squeezed together that one needs a fucking microscope to read them properly.

Bottle, thanks to the great Jimthechap - who should be rating his 2000th these days. Anyway, this beer is golden/copper, crystal clear, with a lovely white head. Very nice, sweet aroma of caramels and raspberry lollies, the frumelo or ricola types. The flavour does have some tropical fruits, a bit of an Asian breakfast basket, with a rather powerful grapefruit bitterness and a touch of pine. Niice and resinous, Id have no reservations on picking this one from a shelf, if I can just remember the novel name.
